name: 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)phenylacetic acid
Reason: 3,5-Bis(trifluoromethyl)phenylacetic acid has a melting point that is influenced by several functional groups. The basic unit for comparison is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C. The trifluoromethyl group (F) increases the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces, estimated at around +10 °C. The phenyl group (C) adds rigidity and pi-stacking interactions, estimated at around +20 °C. The carboxy group (C(=O)O) introduces a hydroxyl group, which raises the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces, estimated at around +5 °C. The methyl group (C(F)(F)F) adds a bulky side chain, estimated at around +5 °C due to steric hindrance and increasing the molecular volume. The fluorine atoms (F) increase the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces, estimated at around +10 °C.
